a horizontal section passing through the central plane, the
nucleus is seen to be occupied by a large cavity (Plate II, Fig. 2) somewhat
irregularly divided by a sinuous partitioning, which always, however,
marks out a central cell <u>a</u> of a somewhat pyriform shape, as distinct
from the space (<u>bb</u>) which surrounds it. The meaning of this feature
is at once made apparent by reference to the disposition of the
sarcode which occupies the cavity of the nucleus; for we then see
(<s>Fig. 3</s> (Plate I, Fig. 5), that the large central pear-shaped cell is occupied by a
mass (<u>a</u>) of corresponding shape, from the small extremity of which
a peduncular process extends, that dilates again into a still larger
mass (<u>b,b</u>) completely surrounding that from which it springs; the
former may be conveniently designated as the 'central'; the latter
as the 'circumambient' segment. In a <u>vertical</u> section of the 
disk, passing through the centre, such as that seen in Plate II
Fig. 3 the nucleus seems to present <u>three</u> chambers; but this is simply
due to the fact that such a section will traverse the circumambient
cell twice, that is, will cut it through on both sides of the central cell
In the section represented in Plate VII, Fig 8, there are but <u>two</u>
central chambers; in this the plane of
